title: Agile Estimation Techniques
description: Master Agile estimation—Planning Poker, T-Shirt sizing, story points vs time estimates, and affinity estimation. Facilitate consensus and uncover hidden assumptions.
objectives: Apply Planning Poker to estimate user stories collaboratively using Fibonacci sequence and team consensus
Use T-Shirt sizing (XS/S/M/L/XL) for rapid estimation of epics and high-level features
Distinguish between story points (abstract complexity/effort/risk) and time-based estimates (hours/days)
Facilitate affinity estimation to quickly categorize large backlogs into relative size groups
Recognize why estimation divergence reveals hidden assumptions and drives valuable discussion
Understand that story points are team-specific and measure velocity, not absolute time

screens.headline: 18 stories. Sprint Planning in 2 hours. Morgan: 'How long will each take?' Alex: 'We don't estimate in hours—we use story points. Here's why.'

dialogue.text: Hours feel precise but they're inaccurate. Story points are abstract, but they're MORE accurate because they measure relative complexity, not time. Let me show you Planning Poker—a technique where the team estimates together.

screens.learningHook: Facilitate Planning Poker for 4 stories, choose the right technique for epics vs stories, and understand why story points beat time estimates.

screens.title: Estimation Scenarios
screens.instructions: Make decisions about Planning Poker facilitation, technique selection, and story point interpretation.

scenarios.title: Planning Poker Divergence
description: Story US-101: 'Filter menu by dietary restrictions.'
Maya reveals: 2 points ('Simple filter logic. I've built this before.')
Devon reveals: 8 points ('Wait, do we have dietary data in the database?')

questions.question: What should Alex (Scrum Master) do when estimates diverge significantly (2 vs 8)?

options.text: Average the estimates (5 points) and move on
Facilitate discussion between Maya (2) and Devon (8) to uncover assumptions—THEN re-estimate
Ask Morgan (PO) to decide the 'correct' estimate
Assign the highest estimate (8) to be safe

feedback.correct: Divergence (2 vs 8) reveals hidden assumptions. Maya assumed data exists; Devon knew schema changes needed. Discussion uncovers gaps—then re-estimate with full context.
feedback.incorrect: Don't average or assign highest. Divergence is valuable learning. Discuss to uncover assumptions, then re-estimate.

scenarios.title: T-Shirt Sizing vs Planning Poker
description: Category A: 18 User Stories (sprint-ready, clear acceptance criteria)
Category B: 5 Epics (high-level, multi-sprint initiatives—Loyalty Program, Social Sharing, etc.)

questions.question: Which estimation technique for each category?

options.text: Planning Poker for BOTH Categories A and B
Planning Poker (Fibonacci) for stories, T-Shirt sizing (XS/S/M/L/XL) for epics
T-Shirt sizing for BOTH Categories A and B
Time estimates (hours) for stories, Story points for epics

feedback.correct: Planning Poker for sprint-ready stories (detailed, discussion-based). T-Shirt sizing for epics (rapid, coarse-grained). Right precision for right context.
feedback.incorrect: Planning Poker is slow but accurate (for stories). T-Shirt sizing is fast but coarse (for epics). Match technique to work type.

scenarios.title: Story Points vs Hours
description: Taylor (new to Agile): 'I estimated 5 points. Morgan asked how many hours. I said 5 hours.'
Morgan scheduled delivery for tomorrow. Maya said it'll take 2 days.
Taylor is confused—what do story points mean?

options.text: Calendar time (5 points = 5 hours)
Team member hours (5 points = 5 person-hours)
Relative complexity, effort, and risk (5-point story is harder than 3-point, but not '5 hours')
Developer productivity (5 points = 5 units of completed work)

feedback.correct: Story points are ABSTRACT—they measure relative complexity, effort, and risk. '5 points' means 'harder than 3, easier than 8,' NOT '5 hours.' Velocity makes points predictable over time.
feedback.incorrect: Story points are NOT time. They measure relative effort/complexity/risk. Track velocity (points/sprint) for predictable delivery.

scenarios.title: Affinity Estimation - Rapid Backlog Sizing
description: Product Backlog: 18 user stories. Sprint Planning in 30 minutes.
No time for detailed Planning Poker discussions for each.
Alex proposes Affinity Estimation: categorize stories into Small/Medium/Large buckets silently, then discuss contested items.

questions.question: What is the PRIMARY benefit of Affinity Estimation over Planning Poker for large backlogs?

options.text: Affinity Estimation is more accurate than Planning Poker
Affinity Estimation is FASTER—18 stories in 15 min vs 90 min with Planning Poker
Affinity Estimation requires less team collaboration
Affinity Estimation works better for small backlogs (1-5 stories)

feedback.correct: Affinity's superpower is SPEED. 18 stories in 15 min vs 90 min with Planning Poker. Trade precision for speed when sizing large backlogs.
feedback.incorrect: Affinity is FASTER, not more accurate. Use for large backlogs, then refine top-priority stories with Planning Poker.

process: PO reads story and acceptance criteria
Silent estimation—each picks a card (avoid anchoring)
Simultaneous reveal—all cards shown at once
Discuss divergence—high and low explain reasoning
content.whySimultaneous: Prevents anchoring bias—if Maya says '2' first, others unconsciously anchor to 2

content.whenToUse: Epics, roadmap planning, quarterly planning. NOT for sprint-ready stories.

problemWithTime: Varies by person (8h senior vs 16h junior)
content.pmbokRef: Agile Practice Guide page 61; PMBOK 7th Ed page 178

correct.text: I wanted to average and move on, but the discussion saved us. Maya's 2 assumed data exists; Devon's 8 accounts for schema work. Discussion prevented mid-sprint surprises.
Story points are team-specific. Your team's 5 points might take 6 hours, another team's 5 might take 12 hours. Focus on consistent relative sizing—velocity makes delivery predictable.

screens.title: Facilitate Planning Poker
screens.context: Story US-210: 'Generate custom menus for catering events.' Round 1: Maya: 3 pts, Devon: 13 pts, Taylor: 8 pts. Divergence reveals Maya thinks pricing exists; Devon knows it's manual in Excel.

questions.question: What does the divergence (3 vs 13) likely reveal?

options.text: Team can't estimate well
Maya and Devon have different assumptions about scope/complexity

questions.question: What's the facilitator's role in Planning Poker?

options.text: Pick the 'correct' estimate for the team
Facilitate discussion, uncover assumptions, help team reach consensus

screens.title: Agile Estimation Mastery
screens.summary: Agile teams estimate using story points (abstract complexity/effort/risk) via Planning Poker (consensus-based). T-Shirt sizing for epics, Affinity Estimation for large backlogs. Divergence is valuable learning.
takeaways: Planning Poker: Simultaneous reveal (avoid anchoring), discuss divergence, re-estimate until consensus
Story Points: Abstract (NOT hours), measure complexity+effort+risk, team-specific
T-Shirt Sizing (XS/S/M/L/XL): Rapid epic estimation for roadmap planning
Affinity Estimation: Fast backlog sizing (15+ stories) into Small/Medium/Large
Estimation Divergence: Valuable learning—uncovers hidden assumptions
Velocity: Points/sprint → predictable delivery without hourly tracking

characterClosing.text: I thought 5 points meant 5 hours. Now I understand—story points measure relative effort, not time. And when Maya said 2 and Devon said 8, the discussion revealed we needed database work. Divergence is the point!
